results.title: Electromagnets and their uses
results.brief_description: Shows how electricity can be used to make magnets, and presents various applications of electromagnets. Describes the effects of coiling a wire and adding a core, and demonstrates the effect of current direction on polarity. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Energy
results.brief_description: Shows the mining of coal, its conversion into electrical energy, and the problems enocuntered in this conversion such as the disposal of waste products. Also looks at atomic power stations and their inherent problems. The concept of tidal power as an alternative source is mentioned. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Lesson for teacher
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style.

results.title: Atmosphere in motion
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explores the causes and effects of atmospheric motion. Time-lapse photography makes the ordinarily slow movement of clouds readily observable and uses experiments to illustrate and explain other atmospheric phenomena.
